text:
Hello Danny! It's 
me grandpa Jon.
I love you buddy.
What's 9+2?

No sorry bud.
9+2 is not 10

That's right!
9+2 equals 11
Great job buddy.

args.text:
Try to get the ice
block to the mark.

If you get stuck,
I'll reset it!

text:
Quack! Hi Danny
I'm a cave duck.
What's 4+7?

Quack!
That's wrong!
4+7 is not 10

Quack!
That's right!
4+7 equals 11

args.text:
Have you tried
using this radio?

Yeah it doesn't
fit does it?

But it's all I
have right now...

text:
Hi there Danny.
I'm your dad.
I love you.
Enjoy your youth.

args.text:
It is now safe to
turn off your
system.

text:
Hi Danny!
It's me daddy.

I'm driving 
the truck!

Where do you
want to go?

It looks like you
did all your math.

Hop on in,
let's go!

Looks like you
haven't done all
your math yet.
Talk to the dog!

Welcome to 
X Street!

Hi Danny! I'm your
neighbor Matt!
What's 6+7?

Woof!
That's wrong!
2+3 is not 4!

Woof!
That's right!
2+3 equals 5!

Look both ways
before crossing!

Hi there.
I'm just a truck.

Where would you
like to go?

It looks like you
did all your math.

Hop on in,
let's go!

Looks like you
haven't done all
your math yet.

Talk to animals
and people!

Welcome to the
Alpine Club!

This is grandpa's
magic cave...
It goes to space!

But unfortunately
it's locked.

You'll need to
find the key.

Maybe ask your
grandpa.
He loves space...

Hi there, I'm a
rock.

If you answer my
math question...
Be careful!

Don't play in 
the street!

Meow?
What's 2+3?

Meow!
That's wrong!
2+3 is not 4!

Meow!
That's right!
2+3 equals 5!

Hi Danny! I'm your
neighbor Matt!
What's 6+7?

Woof!
That's wrong!
2+3 is not 4!

Woof!
That's right!
2+3 equals 5!

Quack! Hi Danny
I'm a cave duck.
What's 4+7?

Quack!
That's wrong!
4+7 is not 10

Quack!
That's right!
4+7 equals 11

Quack! Hi Danny
I'm a cave duck.
What's 4+7?

Quack!
That's wrong!
4+7 is not 10

Quack!
That's right!
4+7 equals 11

Quack! Hi Danny
I'm a cave duck.
What's 4+7?

Quack!
That's wrong!
4+7 is not 10

Quack!
That's right!
4+7 equals 11

Woof! It's me
Frankie the dog.

I snuck in under
the fence...

But don't worry
I'm a good dog!

Anyway, I have
a question...
What's 2x3?

Woof!
That's wrong!
2+3 is not 4!

Woof!
That's right!
2+3 equals 5!

Quack! Hi Danny
I'm a cave duck.
What's 4+7?

Quack!
That's wrong!
4+7 is not 10

Quack!
That's right!
4+7 equals 11

Hi Danny!
I'm the heart.

I pump blood all
over your body.

And never stop
beating.

Anyway, I have
a question...

What bones
protect me?

No, I don't live
in your skull...

That's right! I
live in your ribs!
Good job!

My other body
friends will be
here soon...
Bye for now!

This is the 
syllabus for this
classroom...

This room is for
the organs in the
upper body...

Organs are the
things inside you.

They digest food
and move blood
and let you see.

And everything
else that makes
you alive.

They are all made
of tiny cells that
are also alive.

Even your brain is
an organ!

Anyway answer all
their questions.

Then you can 
move on to the 
next room!

Hi there I'm
an eyeball.

It's nice to see
you again.

I'm sorry that's 
an eyeball joke.

Anyway I'm a very
important organ.

I use special
cells called rods
and cones to see!

They are sensative
to light.

And they send
information to
your brain.

I also have a
lense that you see
in front.

It looks like a
black circle but 
it's really clear!

The inside of me
just looks black.

Because my rods
and cones absorb
all the light!

Also I look like a
circle but I'm 
really a sphere.

I could say a lot
more, I'm a very
cool organ.

But I have a
question for you.

Where do my rods
and cones live?

That's right,
great job!

The retina is
inside me along
my back wall.

It's a thin layer 
of tissue that is

sensitive to 
light.

And it's where 
all my rods and 
cones live!

They're cool
little dudes.
Anyway great job!

Come see me again 
some time.

Sorry that was
another eyeball
joke...

No that's
not right!

The cornea is a
thick clear layer
of the eye.

It protects the
lens which is very
important.

The lens bends
light like
binoculars.

And makes things
look smaller.

So they fit on the
retina for the
rods and cones.

So when you look
at the black
circle on an eye.

You're looking
through the cornea
and the lens.

And seeing the
retina inside
someone's eye!

The cornea is also
very tough.

Because it has an
important job.

To protect
the eye!

Anyway try to
answer my question
again.

You'll get it
right next time!

Hi there, I'm lung
number one.
I breath for you.

And I bring oxygen
from the air to
your blood.

And blood brings
nutrients to every
cell in your body.

Your blood needs
oxygen to move
nutrients.

It's complicated
but very important

Anyway I haven't
thought of a good
question yet.

I'm probably over
thinking it...

But check back
soon!

Hi there I'm 
lung number two.

It's my day off
today.

Try talking to
lung number one.

It's a trash
can...

Hey there's a key
in here!

Someone must have
thrown it away on
accident...

You put the key
in your pocket!

Nothing important
in here...

There are some
random doodles on
the white board...

What do you want
to doodle?

What an awesome
shape!

Wow, your dude has
nine eyes!
And six feet!

This is writing on
a white board...

It says this room
still needs
some organs...
The brain!

And maybe the
trachia...
That's the throat.

And maybe the 
stomach...

And maybe the ear
canal too...
I'm the brain!

I help you 
remember things.
ok bye

That tube is
called your
esophagus!

It connects your
mouth to your
stomach!

When food gets to 
your stomach it
gets digested...

Food is digested
with stomach acid
and enzymes!

And your stomach
shrinks and 
expands...

Depending on how
much food you eat!

Here's your
question...

After the stomach
where does 
digested food go?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

After the 
stomach...

Digested food goes
to the small
intestine!

That's where all
the nutrients
enter the blood.

Anyway bye
for now!

Welcome to Game
Boy University!

This place is here
to help you learn
human anatomy.

Everyone here is
a body part!
In any case.

This is just 
the break room.

Help yourself to
a snack or juice.
No rush.

Hello, I'm 
an eyeball.

I'm not very
talkative.

I'm just taking a
break here.
I needed a snack.

You should talk
to the other eye.
He talks a lot...

Hey there, I'm
trying to nap...

I can't fall
asleep though...

I'll just be
patient and close
my eyes...
And breath slowly.

And think about my
day...

Or should I get
up and get back
to work?

Ok I'm awake,
I'll see you later

Yeah, you're right
sweet dreams
to me...

There are some
scribbled notes...

Talk to 
everyone...

Answer all
questions...
Don't give up...

There is some math
written on the
white board...
x+x=4
That's algebra!

It's a trash
can...

Somebody didn't
recycle their
aluminium can...

Aluminum is
a cool metal...

It's very light
weight...

Even so I'm not
reaching in there.

Hi there! I'm
the skull!

People think I'm
scary but I'm not.

I'm a really
friendly dude.

And I'm a really
important bone!

Actually I'm two
bones because of
my jaw bone.

And speaking of
my jaw bone...

Half of my teeth
live in my jaw!

And that 
reminds me...

I have a question
for you!

How many teeth do
adults have?

No, but you 
were close!

Try again, you'll
get it right
next time!

That's right,
Great job!

Adult skulls have
32 teeth usually.

16 on top and 16
on the bottom.

Teeth live in
your skull but
they aren't bones.

They're made of
different stuff.

They don't fix
themselves if they
break like bones.

And they're only 
for chewing.

Your other bones
don't chew!

Also did you know
there's no bone in
your nose?

It's made of
cartilage.

Cartilage isn't as
hard as bone.

It's bendy so it
doesn't break as
easily.
Anyway good job!

And remember I'm
not scary!

Welcome to the
skeleton room.

Your skeleton is
made of bones

They're hard and
tough like wood.

Not squishy like
your organs.

And they're mostly
not made of cells.

They're mostly
made of collagen
and minerals.

So bones aren't
alive in like your
organs are.

But your bones 
still have some
cells.

Anyway answer all
their questions.

Then you can 
move on to the 
next room!

Hi there, I'm the
rib cage...
I have 24 ribs!

Two collar bones
attach to me on 
the top.

Those are under 
your neck...

And I'm also
attached to your
shoulder blades.

You have two of 
those also...

They're on your
back behind your
shoulders!

In front the ribs 
attach to your 
sternum.

That's in the
middle of your
chest!

This is the 
syllabus for this
classroom...

This room is for
the upper skeleton

The skull the rib
cage and the spine

And other 
connected bones...
Enjoy!

This is writing on
a white board...

It says that the
spine is really
important.

The spine is part
of the skeleton.

It runs along
your back.

From your head to
your butt!

It has 33 bones
in it!

There's some 
writing on this 
white board...

It says the bone
at the bottom of
the spine is...
The sacrum!

It's part of your
pelvis...

It's your butt
bone!

Your butt doesn't
really have a
bone though...

But the sacrum is
the closest!

It's a trash
can...

Nothing important
in here...
Hey hey hey!

I'm your hand
bones!

Your hand has 27
bones in it.
Isn't that crazy?

Your finger bones
are called carpals
and phalanges.

You have 19 
finger bones.

Your phalanges
are right at your 
finger tips.

Your wrist has 8
bones in it.

You can call your
wrist your carpus.

This is writing on
a white board...

It says this room
still needs
one bone...
The scapula!

Also called the
shoulder blade...

It will be here
soon!

This is the 
syllabus for this
classroom...

It says this is
the arm bone room!

It's a trash
can...

There's a pokky
cookie box...
It's half-full...

I shouldn't take
them though...

There might be
something wrong
with them...
Hmmm...

Let me think of a
good question...

Do you remember
how many bones are
in your arm?

That's right
great job!

No that's 
not right!

Your arm has three
bones in it.

The big one close
to your shoulder
is the humerous

The two smaller
ones close to your
hand are...

The radius and the
ulna!

The radius and
ulna are thinner.

And they are right
next to eachother.

Your humerous is
by itself.

Also remember
there are two arms

So that's six arm
bones all together

two humerous bones
two radius bones
and two ulna bones

The arm bones do
a lot of work.

Lots of moving
around...

This is writing on
a white board...

It says this room
still needs
some bones...
The femur...
The knee cap...

Also called the
patella...

The room also
needs the fibia 
and tibia...

Also called the
shin bones...

And finally the
foot bones...

Which includes the
phalanges...

As well as the
tarsals...
And metatarsals!

This is the 
syllabus for this
classroom...

This room is for
the lower skeleton

It's a trash
can...

Nothing important
in here...

I guess they can't
all be winners...

Even in the world
of trash cans...

There are winners
and losers...

This is writing on
a white board...

It says that
there is a way
out of here...

But you need a
secret key...

It says the key is
in a trash can...

Maybe it's a trick
though...

To get me to 
look through 
the trash...
Gross...

Hi there, I'm the
leg bones!

I'm a lot like the
arm bones but
bigger...

And I have a knee
bone called the
patella!

You don't have a
bone like that on
your elbow...

So you have four
bones in your leg.

But only three in
your arm...

But remember the
femur is your
biggest bone.

And your shin bone
is actually two
bones...

Your fibia and 
tibia!

They connect to
your foot.

Anyway bye
for now!
Hello there!

I'm the 
foot bones...

There are a lot
of bones in your
feet...

The toe bones are
phalanges...

Just like in 
your fingers!

Connected to the
phalanges are the
tarsals...

Tarsals are bigger
than phalanges.

Connected to the 
tarsals are the 
meta-tarsals.

They're even 
bigger than
tarsals!

Then there are
more bones near
your ankles...

And that brings me
to your question!

How many bones are
there in your
foot?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

There are 26 bones
in your foot...

Including the
phalanges, tarsals
and meta-tarsals!

All those bones
have 33 joints
connecting them...
So many bones!

Feet are 
complicated...

Anyway bye
for now!

Hi there, I'm
the pelvis...

Also called the
hip bone.

I connect to your
two femurs...

And to the sacrum
in back!

The sacrum is the
bottom of your
spine.

The pelvis is very
important when
you're born...

When your born you
go through your
mom's pelvis!

Hi there, I'm a
locked door...

I go to the
elevator...

Which goes
somewhere...

I don;t know where
the elevator
goes...

I can't find 
out myself...

Since I'm 
just a door...

But if you want
me to unlock...

You have to 
answer everyone's
questions.

You still haven't
answered them all.

Go back and make
sure you've talked
to everyone.

Then I'll 
unlock...
I promise...

You used the key
you found to open
the locked door!

Warning, you're
about to go to 
X Street.

That part of the
game isn't done
yet...

If you go there
you can't come
back here...

Unless you restart
the game.

Are you sure you
want to go?

Hmm... there seems
to be a locked
door here...

Maybe there's a
key around here
somewhere...

There's some 
writing on this
white board...

It says this room
still needs
a lot of organs...
The two kidneys...
The bladder...
The pancreas...

Making video 
games is hard...

This is the 
syllabus for this
classroom...

This room is for
organs in the
lower body.

It's a trash
can...

There's a pokky
cookie box...
It's half-full...

I shouldn't take
them though...

There might be
something wrong
with them...
Hi there.
I'm the liver.

I pronounce it
live-her.

But you can say it
however you want.

I help filter bad
stuff out of your
blood.

So you can feel
healthy.

Anyway I haven't
thought of a 
question yet.

But I'll think of
a good one soon.
I'm just sleepy...

Should I take a
nap on the couch?

Yeah, you're right
I should sleep...

I'll see you
later...

Yeah I'll sleep
later...

Hey there, Im the
stomach!

Your stomach is 
like a food tank 
inside your body.

When you eat your
food travels down 
a tube...

That tube is
called your
esophagus!

It connects your
mouth to your
stomach!

When food gets to 
your stomach it
gets digested...

Food is digested
with stomach acid
and enzymes!

And your stomach
shrinks and 
expands...

Depending on how
much food you eat!

Here's your
question...

After the stomach
where does 
digested food go?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

After the 
stomach...

Digested food goes
to the small
intestine!

That's where all
the nutrients
enter the blood.

Anyway bye
for now!
Hello...

I'm the small
and large
intestines..

I process food
after your stomach
digests it...

The small
intestine absorbs
nutrients...

And transfers it
to the blood...

The large
intestine is
different...

It mostly absorbs
water and deals
with waste...

Your intestines
are full of
bacteria too...

But they're good
not bad...

They help with
digestion!

In any case here's
your question...

What's longer, the
small or large
intestine?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

The small
intestine is 
longer...

It's about 20 feet
long for adults!

The large
intestine is
shorter...

But it'e wider
than the small
intestine!

And last but 
not least remember

The colon is the
last part of the
large intestine...

Your colon is
where poop gets
made!

And it connects
to your anus...
That's your butt!

Hello, Im kidney
number two.

Your stomach is 
like a food tank 
inside your body.

When you eat your
food travels down 
a tube...

That tube is
called your
esophagus!

It connects your
mouth to your
stomach!

When food gets to 
your stomach it
gets digested...

Food is digested
with stomach acid
and enzymes!

And your stomach
shrinks and 
expands...

Depending on how
much food you eat!

Here's your
question...

After the stomach
where does 
digested food go?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

After the 
stomach...

Digested food goes
to the small
intestine!

That's where all
the nutrients
enter the blood.

Anyway bye
for now!

Hi there I'm 
kidney number one.

It's my day off
today.

You should talk
to kidney number
two...

Hello, Im kidney
number two.

Your stomach is 
like a food tank 
inside your body.

When you eat your
food travels down 
a tube...

That tube is
called your
esophagus!

It connects your
mouth to your
stomach!

When food gets to 
your stomach it
gets digested...

Food is digested
with stomach acid
and enzymes!

And your stomach
shrinks and 
expands...

Depending on how
much food you eat!

Here's your
question...

After the stomach
where does 
digested food go?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

After the 
stomach...

Digested food goes
to the small
intestine!

That's where all
the nutrients
enter the blood.

Anyway bye
for now!

Hi... I'm the
pancreas...

Your stomach is 
like a food tank 
inside your body.

When you eat your
food travels down 
a tube...

That tube is
called your
esophagus!

It connects your
mouth to your
stomach!

When food gets to 
your stomach it
gets digested...

Food is digested
with stomach acid
and enzymes!

And your stomach
shrinks and 
expands...

Depending on how
much food you eat!

Here's your
question...

After the stomach
where does 
digested food go?
That's right!

No that's not
right!

After the 
stomach...

Digested food goes
to the small
intestine!

That's where all
the nutrients
enter the blood.

Anyway bye
for now!

There's a single
elevator button...
With no number...
Press the button?

You opened the
elevator door!

There's a crumpled
up note in the 
trash can...

Hello there,
my name is Tom...

I made this place
for a boy named
Danny...

We made it
together...

I hope you like
it here...

But when you're
done come and
find me...
I'll be waiting...

To have a cup
of tea with you...
Open closet door?

There's a crumpled
up note in the 
trash can...

But the ink has
faded...

There's a crumpled
up note in the 
trash can..

Welcome to
the roof...

Please remember
to recycle...

I guess it isn't 
a trash can...
